title: U.S. Military Played No Direct Role in Mali Crisis, Official Says
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004050106" crop="592" type="image"]

A senior American defense official said on Friday that the United States military played no direct role in helping clear the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, Mali, or rescue hostages. 

The official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because of not wanting to get ahead of official statements coming from the Pentagon and the White House, said that reports coming from the hotel throughout the morning had been conflicting, but it now appears that there was only one American service member on the scene. 

The service member helped deal with hostages as they came out of the hotel, the official said, adding that the person may have been in civilian clothes and unarmed. 

Another senior defense official said there are currently 22 Defense Department personnel, both military and civilian, in Mali, and they are all accounted for. The State Department was still trying to account for all its people, the official said.

parent.title: Mali Hotel Attack: Latest Updates on the Hostage Crisis

content_expanded:
A senior American defense official said on Friday that the United States military played no direct role in helping clear the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, Mali, or rescue hostages.

The official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because of not wanting to get ahead of official statements coming from the Pentagon and the White House, said that reports coming from the hotel throughout the morning had been conflicting, but it now appears that there was only one American service member on the scene.

The service member helped deal with hostages as they came out of the hotel, the official said, adding that the person may have been in civilian clothes and unarmed.

Another senior defense official said there are currently 22 Defense Department personnel, both military and civilian, in Mali, and they are all accounted for. The State Department was still trying to account for all its people, the official said.

title: Mali’s President: We ‘Will Have to Get Used to Situations Like This’
content: President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita of Mali told France 24 on Friday that his country "will have to get used to situations like this." Mr. Keita wiped his brow as he spoke to the network from Chad, where the president was on a trip when militants attacked the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako. "We must all remain humble," he added. "No one, no where is safe given the danger of terrorism.”

parent.title: Mali Hotel Attack: Latest Updates on the Hostage Crisis

content_expanded:
President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita of Mali told France 24 on Friday that his country “will have to get used to situations like this.”

Mr. Keita wiped his brow as he spoke to the network from Chad, where the president was on a trip when militants attacked the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako.

“We must all remain humble,” he added. “No one, no where is safe given the danger of terrorism.”

title: Unrest in Northern Mali Has Devastated Tourism Industry
content: [nytmedia id="100000004049963" crop="592" type="image"] Continuing unrest and doubts about security in northern Mali have devastated the country’s floundering tourism industry. About 142,000 international travelers visited the country in 2013, a drop from 160,000 in 2011, according to data kept by the World Bank. Months before Friday's attack on the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, the rise of violent extremism caused some Western governments to issue travel warnings. “Terrorist groups have increased their rhetoric calling for additional attacks or kidnapping attempts on westerners and others, particularly those linked to support for international military intervention,” the U.S. Department of State said in May. France has listed the northern part of the country in its so-called red zone, or places where it encourages citizens not to travel, since shortly after the government was overthrown in 2012. Regarding the Bamako area, the French government has issued regular warnings to its citizens concerning past attacks and kidnappings in the region. People from several nations — including the United States, India, Germany, Belgium, Algeria, France and China — are believed to have been taken hostage inside the hotel.

parent.title: Mali Hotel Attack: Latest Updates on the Hostage Crisis

content_expanded:
Continuing unrest and doubts about security in northern Mali have devastated the country’s floundering tourism industry. About 142,000 international travelers visited the country in 2013, a drop from 160,000 in 2011, according to data kept by the World Bank.

Months before Friday’s attack on the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, the rise of violent extremism caused some Western governments to issue travel warnings.

“Terrorist groups have increased their rhetoric calling for additional attacks or kidnapping attempts on westerners and others, particularly those linked to support for international military intervention,” the U.S. Department of State said in May.

France has listed the northern part of the country in its so-called red zone, or places where it encourages citizens not to travel, since shortly after the government was overthrown in 2012.

Regarding the Bamako area, the French government has issued regular warnings to its citizens concerning past attacks and kidnappings in the region.

People from several nations — including the United States, India, Germany, Belgium, Algeria, France and China — are believed to have been taken hostage inside the hotel.

title: Al Qaeda Supporters Celebrate Mali Attack on Twitter
content: Al Qaeda supporters celebrated the hostage situation at the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, Mali, on Twitter on Friday, praising the attackers for singling out non-Muslims and teasing their jihadist rivals from the Islamic State by saying that they could “learn a thing or two.” One user who said he was in Somalia and posts on Twitter under the name Ibnu Abu Zubayr praised the “lions” who carried out the Mali attack for reports that they let hostages who were able to recite a declaration of Muslim faith, the Shahada, go free. Mr. Zubayr wrote that the attackers did this to “protect the inviolable blood of Muslims.” https://twitter.com/SomQaeda/status/667693622045855744 A Qaeda supporter who said he was in the Syrian province of Latakia agreed. He posted on Twitter under the name Abu Sufyan al-Libi, suggesting that he was Libyan, and his profile was decorated with a banner that said, “The Al Qaeda Organization in the Levant, the Nusra Front.” “This is how Muslims SHOULD act,” he tweeted. The Islamic State, he said, “should learn a thing or two and drop their crooked creed and methodology.” https://twitter.com/sufyanolibyano/status/667704851510468608 “#Mali will always have a special place in our hearts," Mr. Libi later tweeted. Referring to comrades in the fight, he continued: "The ikhwa nearly liberated it all until #France intervened.” “A true Muslim gets happy at whoever attacks the kuffar," he added, referring to non-Muslims, "as long as they are Muslim.”

parent.title: Mali Hotel Attack: Latest Updates on the Hostage Crisis

content_expanded:
Al Qaeda supporters celebrated the hostage situation at the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, Mali, on Twitter on Friday, praising the attackers for singling out non-Muslims and teasing their jihadist rivals from the Islamic State by saying that they could “learn a thing or two.”

One user who said he was in Somalia and posts on Twitter under the name Ibnu Abu Zubayr praised the “lions” who carried out the Mali attack for reports that they let hostages who were able to recite a declaration of Muslim faith, the Shahada, go free. Mr. Zubayr wrote that the attackers did this to “protect the inviolable blood of Muslims.”

Lions who carried out #MaliAttack separated Muslims from Christian in order2 protect the inviolable blood of Muslims https://t.co/hkLMYDwCPD

— Ibnu Abu Zubayr (@SomQaeda) November 20, 2015

A Qaeda supporter who said he was in the Syrian province of Latakia agreed.

He posted on Twitter under the name Abu Sufyan al-Libi, suggesting that he was Libyan, and his profile was decorated with a banner that said, “The Al Qaeda Organization in the Levant, the Nusra Front.”

“This is how Muslims SHOULD act,” he tweeted. The Islamic State, he said, “should learn a thing or two and drop their crooked creed and methodology.”

.@SomQaeda this is how Muslims SHOULD act! #Dawla should learn a thing or two and drop their crooked creed and methodology

— ابو سفيان الليبي (@sufyanolibyano) November 20, 2015

“#Mali will always have a special place in our hearts,” Mr. Libi later tweeted. Referring to comrades in the fight, he continued: “The ikhwa nearly liberated it all until #France intervened.”

“A true Muslim gets happy at whoever attacks the kuffar,” he added, referring to non-Muslims, “as long as they are Muslim.”

title: Mali Hotel Operator Sets Up Support Phone Line for Families
content: [nytmedia id="100000004049826" crop="592" type="image"] The Rezidor Hotel Group said it has set up dedicated phone lines to supply information and support for families of employees and guests who were at the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, Mali, on Friday. Callers in France can dial 0-800-940-164 toll-free, the company said in a statement. From outside France, the number to use is +33-1-7083-7437, the company said.

parent.title: Mali Hotel Attack: Latest Updates on the Hostage Crisis

content_expanded:
The Rezidor Hotel Group said it has set up dedicated phone lines to supply information and support for families of employees and guests who were at the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, Mali, on Friday.

Callers in France can dial 0-800-940-164 toll-free, the company said in a statement. From outside France, the number to use is +33-1-7083-7437, the company said.

title: No More Hostages Held in Mali Hotel, Officials Are Saying
content: [nytmedia id="100000004049774" crop="592" type="image"] Malian officials are telling news outlets that the gunmen at the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako are no longer holding any hostages, but they said the operation against the attackers was still ongoing. According to Reuters, Amadou Sangho, identified as a ministerial adviser, told the French television station BFMTV that all remaining hostages had been freed. "These people have been taken under the wing of the civil authorities," the agency quoted Mr. Sangho as saying. The country’s security minister, Col. Salif Traoré, said much the same at a news conference, the BBC reports. Colonel Traoré said that two of the assailants had been killed by afternoon and the remaining attackers were holed up in a corner of the hotel. A Twitter message from the office of the Malian president commended the country's military and security forces for their professionalism and thanked friendly countries for their help. https://twitter.com/PresidenceMali/status/667731098068238336?ref_src=twsrc^tfw

parent.title: Mali Hotel Attack: Latest Updates on the Hostage Crisis

content_expanded:
Malian officials are telling news outlets that the gunmen at the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako are no longer holding any hostages, but they said the operation against the attackers was still ongoing.

According to Reuters, Amadou Sangho, identified as a ministerial adviser, told the French television station BFMTV that all remaining hostages had been freed. “These people have been taken under the wing of the civil authorities,” the agency quoted Mr. Sangho as saying.

The country’s security minister, Col. Salif Traoré, said much the same at a news conference, the BBC reports.

Colonel Traoré said that two of the assailants had been killed by afternoon and the remaining attackers were holed up in a corner of the hotel.

A Twitter message from the office of the Malian president commended the country’s military and security forces for their professionalism and thanked friendly countries for their help.

Le Pdt #IBK salue le professionnalisme des forces de défense et de sécurité du Mali et remercie les pays amis pour leur assistance #Radisson

— Presidence Mali (@PresidenceMali) November 20, 2015

title: Dozens Killed in Mali Siege, U.N. Official Says
content: [nytmedia id="100000004050104" crop="592" type="image"] A senior United Nations official said that as many as 27 people had been killed so far at a siege on a hotel in Bamako, Mali, according to a preliminary assessment. Other preliminary reports put the death toll lower, at about 17. The dead include bodies found in the basement and on the second floor of the Radisson Blu hotel.

parent.title: Mali Hotel Attack: Latest Updates on the Hostage Crisis

content_expanded:
A senior United Nations official said that as many as 27 people had been killed so far at a siege on a hotel in Bamako, Mali, according to a preliminary assessment.

Other preliminary reports put the death toll lower, at about 17.

The dead include bodies found in the basement and on the second floor of the Radisson Blu hotel.

title: Al Mourabitoun Claims Responsibility for Mali Siege, Al Jazeera Reports
content:
Al Mourabitoun, a militant Islamist organization that comprises Tuaregs and Arabs from northern Mali, has taken responsibility for the hostage siege in Bamako, Al Jazeera reports.

The group provided an audio recording to Al Jazeera saying that it had undertaken the raid on the Radisson Blu hotel with Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, the network reported. (The news network did not publish a copy of the recording.)

Al Mourabitoun demanded that Malian authorities release imprisoned fighters held in Bamako and stop "aggression" in northern Mali.

"If you refuse, you know the consequences," the group warned in a message to Malian and French authorities, Al Jazeera said.

parent.title: Mali Hotel Attack: Latest Updates on the Hostage Crisis

content_expanded:
Al Mourabitoun, a militant Islamist organization that comprises Tuaregs and Arabs from northern Mali, has taken responsibility for the hostage siege in Bamako, Al Jazeera reports.

The group provided an audio recording to Al Jazeera saying that it had undertaken the raid on the Radisson Blu hotel with Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, the network reported. (The news network did not publish a copy of the recording.)

Al Mourabitoun demanded that Malian authorities release imprisoned fighters held in Bamako and stop “aggression” in northern Mali.

“If you refuse, you know the consequences,” the group warned in a message to Malian and French authorities, Al Jazeera said.

title: Despite Peacekeeping Efforts, China Unlikely to Help Free Hostages
content:
Mali suddenly became an important African country for China in 2013 when Beijing sent combat troops to serve in the United Nations peacekeeping effort there. It was the first time that China, a heavy contributor to United Nations peacekeeping, had deployed combat soldiers on such a mission. The move was considered a major change in China's stance of remaining far away from any involvement in civil conflict.

The state-run newspaper People's Daily said in May that China sent its third batch of soldiers to Mali, a contingent of 395 peacekeepers, serving in the eastern part of the country, about 700 miles from the capital. Given the distance from the hotel siege, and other considerations, it seemed unlikely the Chinese soldiers would be involved in the operation to free the hostages.

parent.title: Mali Hotel Attack: Latest Updates on the Hostage Crisis

content_expanded:
Mali suddenly became an important African country for China in 2013 when Beijing sent combat troops to serve in the United Nations peacekeeping effort there. It was the first time that China, a heavy contributor to United Nations peacekeeping, had deployed combat soldiers on such a mission. The move was considered a major change in China’s stance of remaining far away from any involvement in civil conflict.

The state-run newspaper People’s Daily said in May that China sent its third batch of soldiers to Mali, a contingent of 395 peacekeepers, serving in the eastern part of the country, about 700 miles from the capital. Given the distance from the hotel siege, and other considerations, it seemed unlikely the Chinese soldiers would be involved in the operation to free the hostages.

title: Footage of Security Forces Evacuating the Hotel
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004049644" crop="480" type="video" autostart="false"]

Footage from inside the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, Mali, shows security forces evacuating guests as attackers held others hostage.
